article_title: The Vandal Conquest of North Africa
article_text_raw:
# The Vandal Conquest of North Africa

## Background and Origins

The Vandals were an East Germanic people who, along with groups like the Goths, Burgundians, and Rugians, emerged in eastern Germania during the 1st and 2nd centuries AD [2]. Traditional scholarship suggests these groups migrated from prehistoric Scandinavia across the Baltic Sea, settling in continental Europe during the early imperial age [2]. The Vandals underwent a transformation from primarily farmers to a society centered on horse breeding and mounted warfare, heavily influenced by Sarmatians and Alans [6]. This 'Sarmatisation' affected their warfare, economy, dressing, and conduct [6]. By the 5th century, the Vandals had become a major force impacting the Roman world [9].

## The Vandal Migration and Invasion

In 406 AD, a confederation of Vandals, Alans, and Sueves crossed the Rhine River into Roman Gaul [35]. This event is considered a key moment in the decline of the Western Roman Empire [65]. The reasons for this crossing included the westward movement of the Huns, divisions within the Roman Empire, and the desire to escape Hun-generated chaos [23]. The Vandals bypassed Constantine III's armies and crossed the Pyrenees into Spain in 409 AD [35]. By 417, the Visigoths were enlisted to fight against the Vandals and Alans in Spain [56]. In September 409, the Vandals began setting up kingdoms in northern Spain [56]. The Asding and Siling Vandals crossed the frozen Rhine on New Year's Eve 406 [56].

In 429 AD, the Vandals, under the leadership of King Geiseric (also known as Genseric), crossed from Spain to North Africa [56, 71, 93]. This invasion marked a turning point in the history of North Africa [105]. The Vandal conquest was facilitated by internal strife within Roman Africa, including the Donatist religious conflict [74]. The Donatist schism, which began in the early 4th century, significantly destabilized the region [74]. The Vandals initially landed in Tingitania [56].

## Conquest and Establishment of the Vandal Kingdom

The Vandals moved through North Africa, besieging Hippo in 430 AD [29, 74]. Augustine of Hippo died during this siege [29]. The Vandals captured Hippo in August 431 [74, 135]. The Vandals occupied Carthage in 439 AD [9, 21, 93]. This marked a transition from a tribe under the shadow of the Western Roman Empire to a powerful kingdom [9]. The Vandal kingdom in Africa was established in 429 AD and lasted for a hundred years [21].

In 442 AD, a treaty between the Vandal king Genseric and the Roman Empire recognized the Vandals as an independent kingdom [56]. The Vandals dominated Mediterranean politics between 450 and 500 [9]. The Vandal kingdom included Africa Proconsularis, Africa Byzacena, and eastern Numidia [30].

## Vandal Rule and Society

The Vandal kingdom in North Africa was heavily influenced by Roman imperialism [10]. Roman imperialism impacted the Vandals' attitudes towards Roman culture, governmental structures, and Romans themselves [10]. The Vandals shaped their conquered territories into kingdoms that benefited their own interests [10]. The Vandals dominated Mediterranean politics between 450 and 500 [9].

The Vandals, followers of Arian Christianity, persecuted Nicene Christians in North Africa [27, 47]. Victor of Vita's 'History of the Vandal Persecution' is a key source for understanding this period [7, 11]. The Vandal master, in one narrative, tortured the slaves and forced them to be rebaptized [7]. Quodvultdeus, a bishop of Carthage, was banished by Gaiseric [8].

The Vandal kingdom engaged in maritime activities, including raiding the Mediterranean Sea [45]. The Vandals conquered the Balearic Islands in 455 AD [5]. They also launched incursions into Sicily, Sardinia, and Corsica [30]. The Vandals sacked Rome in 455 AD [28, 45, 46, 61, 95]. This event led to the coining of the term 'vandalism', meaning senseless spoiling [45].

## Internal Conflicts and Decline

After Geiseric's death in 477 AD, the Vandal kingdom faced internal challenges [21]. Huneric (477-484 AD) confronted the Catholic Church [21]. Thrasamund (496-523 AD) is associated with a cultural and scientific center at the Vandal court [21]. Hilderic's pro-Roman policies led to a coup by Gelimer in 532 AD [21].

## The Byzantine Reconquest

Gelimer's coup d'état in 532 AD led to the intervention of Emperor Justinian I and the invasion of Belisarius [21, 27, 47]. Belisarius' campaign revealed the military weaknesses of the Vandal kingdom [21]. The Vandals were conquered in 534 by Iustinianos as part of his effort to restore Rome [9]. The conquest by Iustinianos in 534 led to the Vandals' disappearance from history [9]. The Byzantines became the heirs of Roman Africa [21].

## Historiography and Legacy

Historians have not given the Vandals enough attention despite their large impact on the Roman world [9]. The perception of Vandal Africa is shaped by varied sources and voices from different periods and rulers [20]. Recent scholarship aims to present a more balanced picture of Vandal Africa, moving away from Victor of Vita's negative depiction [11]. The Vandals lacked a 'national' historiographer to document their accomplishments [20]. The article "Contemporary historiography on christianity in Vandal and Byzantine Africa (1785-2020)" examines the historiography of Christianity in North Africa during the Vandal and Byzantine periods [12].
